ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Chinese writing, reading, speaking, and listening skills. Topics ranged from ordering food to doing international business trade. More than just elementary language study.
I learned Chinese to improve my speaking, reading, and writing skills.
I gained a lot of vocabulary and grammar skills for writing and speaking Chinese.
The intricacies of Chinese grammar and vocabulary at a high level. Insight into Chinese culture through the lens of the textbook
I improved all areas of my Chinese this semester, especially my speaking ability
reading, writing, and speaking skills were greatly developed
By taking this course I was able to expand my speaking knowledge and skills and knowledge about Chinese history and culture.
Greatly expanded Chinese vocabulary, solidified and enhanced command of Chinese grammar -- I can have meaningful conversations in Chinese about my life and Chinese culture!
I learned a lot more chinese than I did.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course was structured really well.
I think it is very well organized on Canvas which is nice. I wish there was more listening practice since I struggled with that a lot.

Strengths: how often it meets means that there is consistency and discipline when taking this course
weakness: I prefer having a slideshow as the class goes on with content on the slides, not just on small notecards.
Less partner work, I dont think this was too beneficial
I definitely think Sun Laoshi is a strength of this course. Her passion and excitement for the class keeps everyone engaged.

The strengths of this course are overwhelming -- the professors have tons of experience, the textbook and class materials are very interesting, and every assignment is designed to maximize your learning.
Strengths were a great teacher, weaknesses were a lack of applicability: too many essays and not enough everyday situations.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! If you want to learn Chinese and continue upon the foundations of study you have previously built. This class is not easy and not for everyone. It is not what you take just to get your language requirement out of the way.
Yes, it was a really good course to improve my chinese.
I would recommend it if you want to learn Chinese, but it is definitely a lot of work. It is very rewarding, and all of the Chinese teachers are incredible.
Yes, if you are looking for a heightened ability to read, write, speak and listen in chinese, this is the class for you.
Definitely, I love learning Chinese it is my favourite language and I would recommend it to anyone to try
yes, the mandarin department at Yale is very well organized

Yes. I would recommend it for anyone that has a little bit of extra time for homework though because although it is interesting the time commitment is in my experience greater than that of my other classes.
If you want to solidify what you learned in L3 and reach a new level in your knowledge, you should absolutely take L4 Chinese at Yale.
I would recommend it to people want to improve their chinese.
